Long, long before he was Obi-Wan Kenobi, Alec Guinness was chemist Sydney Stratton, in 'The Man in the White Suit', who invented a nearly indestructible, self-cleaning fabric. He's a hero - until textile management and workers unions realize what this "forever fabric" would mean in the long run... and he becomes a fugitive.

I looked for infrared (IR) footage of Polar bears and found bearly (sorry) nothing but I'd say that it is pretty conclusive that they are not invisible in IR. https://youtu.be/AVp3wc-DLMc?t=99, at 1:39 they are clearly discernible. What I did found a ton of was videos without sources or evidence claiming Polar bears are almost if not totally invisible in IR, please don't get me wrong, using IR to find something that well insulated is definitely going to be hard, they are very well camouflaged in both IR and visible light, but from that to invisible that's quite a leap.

man... it's super annoying when sci show hypes up in process research and then pretends that its a fully developed widespread thing. Neither Kurare(i)? with their supposed "Diphorl" nor Teijin with their Morphotex are producing EITHER of those fabrics for mass consumption or even at a level where interested people could inquire individually unless they are major investors and contributors. At this point not even google will turn up any kind of results if you search for Diphorl AT ALL. And as far as Morphotex is concerned they have something like two or three samples of the fabric on two or three items which they made - and those items look something like Squirrel grey with little catches of color shine that peek through here and there. And they DO NOT provide samples let alone produce this fabric for consumptive use or interest.
